update.description:
* added force visual plugin

Uncomment code in wamv\_gazebo/wamv\_gazebo.xacro to enable support
update.title: Issue#109 force visualize
update.reason: Please, reopen in the future when we address the outstanding comments.

content.raw:
I was thinking of creating a mock environment in gazebo with different forces on primatives and visualizing it. This was I should be able to pinpoint the issue quickly.

I thought we wanted to zero the forces in world and not body frame. Could you elaborate on that?
content.html:
I was thinking of creating a mock environment in gazebo with different forces on primatives and visualizing it. This was I should be able to pinpoint the issue quickly.

I thought we wanted to zero the forces in world and not body frame. Could you elaborate on that?

content.raw:
I propose we put this on the back burner for now.  It is certainly “nice to have”, but not critical path for this year’s competition.

To debug, I would recommend that we explicitly specify a link \(or links\) for displaying the vector.  For example the “left\_propeller\_link” is where the thrust plugin applies the propulsion force.  Verifying that the applied proplusion force is consistent with the link->WorldForce\(\) might shed some light on why things aren’t showing up as expected.

Also, it appears that the disable\_z parameter zeros the z component of force in the world frame.  I believe what we want is to zero the z component in the body frame.  This would require 1\) rotating force  vector into body frame, 2\) zeroing the z component, 3\) rotating back into world frame for display.

Looking into this briefly it seemed like there was a lack of documentation on the ignition msg marker functionality.  Helpful bits are [here](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/07607e5f1e77eceec0273f6c73cee5aaa5768fe4/ignition/msgs/marker.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default), this [example](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3ca3431cfe5a/examples/stand_alone/marker/marker.cc) and this [PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2498/markers/diff) from 2016.  Perhaps I’m missing something obvious.
content.html:
I propose we put this on the back burner for now. It is certainly “nice to have”, but not critical path for this year’s competition.

To debug, I would recommend that we explicitly specify a link (or links) for displaying the vector. For example the “left_propeller_link” is where the thrust plugin applies the propulsion force. Verifying that the applied proplusion force is consistent with the link->WorldForce() might shed some light on why things aren’t showing up as expected.

Also, it appears that the disable_z parameter zeros the z component of force in the world frame. I believe what we want is to zero the z component in the body frame. This would require 1) rotating force vector into body frame, 2) zeroing the z component, 3) rotating back into world frame for display.

Looking into this briefly it seemed like there was a lack of documentation on the ignition msg marker functionality. Helpful bits are here, this example and this PR from 2016. Perhaps I’m missing something obvious.

content.raw: Yes I agree. I don’t think it is working properly. The logic is very simple so I am very confused as to why it is not working.
content.html: Yes I agree. I don’t think it is working properly. The logic is very simple so I am very confused as to why it is not working.

content.raw: I think it is cleaner to merge the PR after we have a working tutorial that serves as a test case for verification.
content.html: I think it is cleaner to merge the PR after we have a working tutorial that serves as a test case for verification.

content.raw: That looks consistent with what I’m seeing.  Does it make sense with what you are expecting?    I would expect to see a dominant force vector on the left, pointing straight ahead.
content.html: That looks consistent with what I’m seeing. Does it make sense with what you are expecting? I would expect to see a dominant force vector on the left, pointing straight ahead.

content.raw:
I applied a 20% effort on the left thruster.

This is what it looks on my end: [https://vimeo.com/356240006](https://vimeo.com/356240006)
content.html:
I applied a 20% effort on the left thruster.

This is what it looks on my end: https://vimeo.com/356240006

content.raw: Does it look different on your end?  Perhaps we aren’t running the same demo.
content.html: Does it look different on your end? Perhaps we aren’t running the same demo.

content.raw: Yuh that’s confusing. I have no idea why that is happening. Maybe how I am displaying the forces is my guess.
content.html: Yuh that’s confusing. I have no idea why that is happening. Maybe how I am displaying the forces is my guess.

content.raw: The reason I did this was if someone wanted to use the plugin without having to set the flag they can just not include the envflag tag. Removes dependance from always having to set a flag
content.html: The reason I did this was if someone wanted to use the plugin without having to set the flag they can just not include the envflag tag. Removes dependance from always having to set a flag

content.raw:
I ran a simple verification test and am having a hard time interpreting the results.  

1. Ran wayfinding,launch
2. Used rostopic pub to send thrust to right thruster.

I expected to see a thrust vector on the right thruster, purely forward in the body frame, and little or now thrust vectors at the left and lateral thruster.    What I see is thrust vectors on all thrusters.  The left and right vectors are about the same magnitude and neither is straight forward in the body frame.  

See video example: [https://vimeo.com/356233412](https://vimeo.com/356233412)

Perhaps I’m misinterpreting?
content.html:
I ran a simple verification test and am having a hard time interpreting the results.

  1. Ran wayfinding,launch
  2. Used rostopic pub to send thrust to right thruster.

I expected to see a thrust vector on the right thruster, purely forward in the body frame, and little or now thrust vectors at the left and lateral thruster. What I see is thrust vectors on all thrusters. The left and right vectors are about the same magnitude and neither is straight forward in the body frame.

See video example: https://vimeo.com/356233412

Perhaps I’m misinterpreting?

content.raw: I find this a bit non-intuitive.  I would recommend that the “envflag” be a required SDF tag.
content.html: I find this a bit non-intuitive. I would recommend that the “envflag” be a required SDF tag.

content.raw: Sounds good. I will finalize the tutorial once we close this PR.
content.html: Sounds good. I will finalize the tutorial once we close this PR.

update.description:
* added force visual plugin

Uncomment code in wamv\_gazebo/wamv\_gazebo.xacro to enable support
update.title: Issue#109 force visualize

content.raw:
I have addressed all the comments.

Enable disable is now controlled by an environment flag. If the SDF has an envflag param then the system needs a flag by that name to disable force visualizations.
content.html:
I have addressed all the comments.

Enable disable is now controlled by an environment flag. If the SDF has an envflag param then the system needs a flag by that name to disable force visualizations.

update.description:
* added force visual plugin

Uncomment code in wamv\_gazebo/wamv\_gazebo.xacro to enable support
update.title: Issue#109 force visualize

content.raw: I have added this as a configurable feature
content.html: I have added this as a configurable feature

content.raw: Yes default is 1.0 aka no scaling. And since its just a factor it has no units \(i think\)
content.html: Yes default is 1.0 aka no scaling. And since its just a factor it has no units (i think)

content.raw: Would it be appropriate to eliminate the vertical component of the force vector \(z in the body frame\)?  This would show only the horizontal force components, which I believe would be the pertinent aspects for debugging the control.
content.html: Would it be appropriate to eliminate the vertical component of the force vector (z in the body frame)? This would show only the horizontal force components, which I believe would be the pertinent aspects for debugging the control.

content.raw:
To let folks know that this feature exists we’ll need a short tutorial.

1. How to enable the feature
2. A simple example showing what to expect and how to interpret the force vectors, perhaps illustrated by annotating some illustrative images.
content.html:
To let folks know that this feature exists we’ll need a short tutorial.

  1. How to enable the feature
  2. A simple example showing what to expect and how to interpret the force vectors, perhaps illustrated by annotating some illustrative images.

content.raw:
If it is optional - is the default 1.0?

Are there units to the scaling, e.g., m/N?
content.html:
If it is optional - is the default 1.0?

Are there units to the scaling, e.g., m/N?

content.raw: We draw the total force on each link. If I make the WAM-V vector green then the plugin won’t be as generic. Thoughts?
content.html: We draw the total force on each link. If I make the WAM-V vector green then the plugin won’t be as generic. Thoughts?

content.raw: Yes I was thinking the same thing but do you have a suggestion as to how I can do it?
content.html: Yes I was thinking the same thing but do you have a suggestion as to how I can do it?

content.raw: Could you use `\param[in]`  and `\return` instead?
content.html: Could you use \param[in] and \return instead?

update.description:

Uncomment code in wamv\_gazebo/wamv\_gazebo.xacro to enable support
update.title: Issue#109 force visualize

content.raw: Would it be more intuitive if `this->scaling` is a factor that is multiplied to the `force`? That way the interpretation is easier \(I think\). In this case, you're scaling should be converted to `0.05`instead.
content.html: Would it be more intuitive if this->scaling is a factor that is multiplied to the force? That way the interpretation is easier (I think). In this case, you're scaling should be converted to 0.05instead.

content.raw: This could be a local variable in `Load()`, as it’s not used outside of that method.
content.html: This could be a local variable in Load(), as it’s not used outside of that method.

content.raw: This will create a lot of errors on Gazebo 7. How about adding the `GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION >= 8` check in `Load()`, when you're connecting the `WorldUpdateBegin` event with `ForceVisualPlugin::Update`. That way, if you're not using Gazebo 8\+ you get an error but don't keep executing `Update()`.
content.html: This will create a lot of errors on Gazebo 7. How about adding the GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION >= 8 check in Load(), when you're connecting the WorldUpdateBegin event with ForceVisualPlugin::Update. That way, if you're not using Gazebo 8+ you get an error but don't keep executing Update().

content.raw: You don’t need this entire block, there’s no need to advertise a topic if you’re interested on requesting a service.
content.html: You don’t need this entire block, there’s no need to advertise a topic if you’re interested on requesting a service.

content.raw: Could you add a new entry to the `Changelog.md`, please?
content.html: Could you add a new entry to the Changelog.md, please?

content.raw: If I interpret it correctly, there is a vector per thruster and another one from the WAM-V origin. Could you make the WAM-V vector green maybe to make it more evident that this is the total force vector?
content.html: If I interpret it correctly, there is a vector per thruster and another one from the WAM-V origin. Could you make the WAM-V vector green maybe to make it more evident that this is the total force vector?

content.raw: It would be great if we could enable/disable via a parameter without touching the code.
content.html: It would be great if we could enable/disable via a parameter without touching the code.
